B000B7BRMM|4.0|Those of us who felt a little uncomfortable with Diana Krall's last two studio albums will be relieved to learn that for this foray into the old Christmas roast chestnuts she has managed without the services of both her husband and the over-lush full orchestra with which they were handicapped. Further than that, she has resisted the usual temptation to slip in a new or self-penned song, so that we are spared the inevitable, if unfair, comparison with the songs which stood the test of their 50+ years longevity. <br /> <br />She does bring to the party the Clayton/Hamilton Jazz Orchestra, who blow smoothly and roundly behind her on the more uptempo numbers - actually I thought they were a bit too polished and could have done with a bit more in the power department. Nevertheless, \\"Jingle Bells\\", \\"Let It Snow\\", \\"Santa Claus Is Comin'...\\" and \\"Winter Wonderland\\" all swing along nicely, with Diana playing games here and there, ad-libbing and lapsing into scat, and evoking the ghosts of Christmases past - Ella and Dino and Sinatra. <br /> <br />Where the pace drops off is where Diana performs best - the more intimate, jazz quartet settings of \\"The Christmas Song\\" \\"I'll Be Home...\\" and \\"What Are You Doing New Year's Eve?\\" and, for anyone who has ever wanted to dance to \\"White Christmas\\", it's done in smoochy slow-time, as near to a waltz as the tune will allow. <br /> <br />Johnny Mandel contributes inimitably subtle and understated arrangements and orchestrations for three tracks, including the slinky \\"Have Yourself A Merry Little Christmas\\" and Irving Berlin's dreamy lullaby \\"Count Your Blessings Instead Of Sheep\\", not actually a Christmas song but a perfect ending to the album.  <br /> <br />Throughout Diana sings, and plays her Steinway, with the clarity, elegance and polish we have come to expect over the last ten years or so. If I were picky I would say that it is perhaps a little too squeaky clean and clinical - it is arguably a good thing that there's a complete absence (musically) of neighing reindeer or jangling bells, but just a little more colour and passion would have been welcome and would have elevated this Christmas album to rank with the very best.
B00008G6EZ|5.0|[This DVD can also be bought as part of a recently released twofer that also includes the Zurich Opera production of Cos&igrave; fan tutte, also with Bartoli. I don't know if there is a price break for the twofer or not.]<br /><br />Of the three Don Giovanni DVDs that I own, I think I like this one best. First of all, musically it is superb. I've never heard a better Donna Elvira than that of Cecilia Bartoli; Elvira is meant to be a force of nature (yet a woman underneath) and Bartoli is certainly that. Her singing is, of course, unimaginably good. Her acting as the wronged Elvira crackles. And her momentary softening in Act II is also believable. Her 'Ah, fuggi il traditor' and 'Mi tradi' are simply outstanding, both musically and dramatically. Rodney Gilfry has a light, flexible baritone which is, I believe, precisely what Mozart wanted -- otherwise why would he have written the Champagne Aria to be sung at that killing tempo? -- and Gilfry has that. In addition, he is the handsomest Don around these days; he is charming, not playing the Don as an out and out villain but as a spoiled rich boy who feels entitled to whatever he wants. Gilfry, you will recall, created the part of Stanley Kowalski in Andr&eacute; Previn's Streetcar Named Desire, and obviously that required an animalistic quality that he is able to portray, appropriate for the role of the Don as well. Laszl&oacute; Polg&aacute;r as Leporello has a resonant bass-baritone, easily distinguished from that of the Don; but when they exchange places in Act II he lightens his voice (as Gilfry darkens his) and the impersonation seems believable. He plays Leporello as a darker, more saturnine character than we usually see, not just playing it for laughs as many do. His 'Madamina, il catalogo' is played for shock, not comedy, and sung very nicely, too.<br /><br />The other singers in this Zurich Opera production are just as good. Isabel Rey, a soprano with a rather soft-cored voice, is an aristocratic, noble Donna Anna. Liliana Nikiteanu is a properly peasant Zerlina, but no dummy. She shines, with Gilfry, in 'La ci darem la mano.' Don Ottavio is sung by the Italian lyric tenor, Robert Sacc&agrave;, and his 'Il mio tesoro' is a highlight. Oliver Widmer does well by Masetto, although his acting is a bit generic; the voice is flexible and his participation in the various ensembles is fine. (By the way, I could not get 'Batti, batti, o bel Masetto' out of my head for hours after I heard Zerlina sing it to him. Well, if you have to have an earworm it might as well be Mozart, no?)<br /><br />Matti Salminen is a suitably sonorous Commendatore. Why he appears in person, rather as the statue, at the end of the opera I don't know. This is not a particularly tradition-breaking production although the costumes are a sort of generic early 19th-century sort, and the sets are minimalistic. This is a dark Don Giovanni but the lighting is so expert that one does not have the feeling that one is having to squint to see the singers. This  is due partly because the camerawork -- the video was directed by the redoubtable Brian Large -- is expert. There are lots of close-ups and two-shots and they are appropriately chosen, often being of reactions rather than trained on the singer of the moment. A nice touch. Orchestral and choral support is wonderful, all under the direction of a conductor whom I admire more and more: Nikolaus Harnoncourt.<br /><br />The opera is spread over two DVDs -- for a total of 275 minutes which includes a 'behind the scenes' extra with commentary by Harnoncourt, Bartoli, Gilfry and Rey. Sound is PCM Stereo or Dolby 5.1; Subtitles: Italian, German, French, English, Spanish, Japanese.<br /><br />I recommend this Don Giovanni for its dramatic as well as its musical values.<br /><br />Scott Morrisona Anna. Liliana Nikiteanu is a properly peasant Zerlina, but no dummy. She shines, with Gilfry, in 'La ci darem la mano.' 6305736650|5.0|If you were to read my reviews you would see that I often comment that a classic movie or book isn't as great as it's cracked up to be.  For example, Citizen Kane is a mediocre movie, and 8 1/2 is nothing.  Shakespeare comedies are often little more than stupid, sorry re-runs of each other, with the same stupid tricks in them.  The Scarlet Letter by Hawthorne is silly garbage, as is the rest of Hawthorne's writing.  I'm an iconoclast.  I don't do it to be different.  I do it because I believe it.  I call them as I see them.<br /><br />Casablanca is in the running for the greatest movie ever made.  It is uplifting and emotional.  You can't ask for more.<br /><br />One of my favorite scenes is the one in Rick's when the Germans begin singing their song, and Laszlo decides not to take it.  He orders the band to play the Marseillaise, and the crowd at Rick's drowns out the Germans.<br /><br />The symbolism is obvious rather than subtle, but I like it that way.  I like the way the French police captain tosses a bottle of Vichy water into the trash and kicks it.  It's not a little \\"in\\" joke for the initiated.  It is as subtle as a rap in the head.  That's the way it should be.<br /><br />World War Two was the single most important event in human history.  You can't get emotional about other wars.  They are all controversial.  This one isn't.  This was the only war I know of that was really good vs evil.  Other wars are shades of gray against each other, with both good and evil on both sides.<br /><br />I'm sure you know the plot.  I just need to cast my vote and reward this wonderful movie with the highest rating.

6305508550|4.0|After being pestered my many people for years to see this movie, I have finally gotten around to it.  The thing I guess I should say first is that while this is definitely a very funny movie, I think that it is somewhat overhyped.  I don't want people to think that it doesn't deserve most of the praise it receives, for it is very enjoyable and very accurate.  However, it isn't as groundbreaking/defining as many people make it out to be.  Still, it's a fun movie that everyone should see at least once. <br />Peter Gibbons (Ron Livingston) is a mid-level corporate drone working for a generic software company, and it doesn't look like he's going anywhere in life.  His best friends Michael Bolton (David Herman), who has no relation to the singer, and Samir Nagheenanajar (Ajay Naidu), who is tired of Americans being unable to pronounce his name, are also employed at Initech, and have similar outlooks for the future.  The three spend their days hitting the printer that always jams and going to Chotchkie's, a TGIFridays-type restaurant that employs the beautiful Joanna (Jennifer Aniston), who Peter constantly pines for.  The other people in Peter's life include Anne (Alexandra Wentworth), his girlfriend whom he believes is cheating on him, Lawrence (the underused Diedrich Bader), his construction worker neighbor, Milton (Stephen Root), a mumbling coworker whose only loves in life are his radio and his red Swingline stapler, and Bill Lumbergh (Gary Cole), his evil, soulless boss who makes him work on the weekends and always starts sentences with \\"Uh, yeah, what's happening?\\". <br />When Peter is brought to see an occupational hypnotherapist, the doc does wonders for him.  He is able to get Peter completely relaxed, but before he can wake Peter up, he keels over from a heart attack.  Now, Peter hasn't a care in the world.  He skips work, breaks up with Ann, and asks out Joanna.  And amazingly, just when Lumbergh is going to fire him, two \\"efficiency consultants\\" (played by John C. McGinley and Paul Willson) observe Peter's behavior and believe that he just isn't being challenged enough at work, and they reccomend him for a promotion! <br />Eventually, using his newfound apathy, Peter decides that they should make good on Michael's constant quips about how he could write a virus that could scam Initech for millions.  Of course, things don't go as planned, and the results are of coures hilarious. <br />This movie has often been lauded as being one of the greatest corporate satires ever made.  While I believe that it does get many things right, I don't think that this is anything new.  That doesn't prevent the movie from being funny, though.  Lumbergh's whole schtick about his personality and mannerisms is one of the greatest characterizations I've seen in years.  Furthermore, the whole Milton subplot where he is constantly being relocated by Lumbergh is fun just to see what Milton will mumble next.  I also now understand a lot of the things that I've heard people say in regards to this film (the case of the Mondays things is the most prominent). <br />Overall, this is a film that most people, especially those who work for corporations like Initech, should see at least once.  My biggest gripe was the use of a lot of rap music, which I don't particularly care for, so if that's the biggest problem, that's not bad at all.  While it may not deserve all the hype it receives, there is still a lot of good to be said for Office Space.
0743454537|3.0|There is something about this book that makes it very readable- a page turner even- but something else that made me hate it.   <br />The subject matter is extremely interesting- and something you don't normally hear about- but the way that it's written is, at times, cringe inducing.   <br />This was my first experience reading one of Picoult's books- what struck me most about her writing style is her apparent love of cliches.  You can pick out at least one on every page.  I'm assuming this is an effort to make her characters seem smooth- maybe \\"real\\".  After the first 100 pages, it gets annoying. <br />Her dialouge is bulky and, while I know my share of bright \\"old for their age\\" 13 year olds, I don't know any who are as smooth as the character of Anna.     <br />She describes everything- which can be nice, but, as an acting teacher once told me, \\"you should never guild the lily.\\"  Picoult's lily is dripping... <br /> <br />The story itself was extremely interesting, and I finished the book in spite of not caring for the writing style. B00008G7UJ|5.0|After peeking at the reviews already written for this movie, I thought that perhaps I could share my two cents. <br /> <br />First of all, no. This is not set in the 16th century. This is not in Italy. They do not use actual swords (though if you watch, most of their guns are named after the classic 16th century weaponry).  <br /> <br />However, that's not what Baz Luhrmann was after. He wanted to take the story and, with as few script/theme/feeling changes as possible, make it present day. He wanted to show audiences the timelessness of the story, the ways in which it still could apply to modern times and modern people. He managed to create a feud between two families that seemed a real and common part of these characters' lives, while still managing to convey a true love story. Some may think that the love is too playful, too childish, but that's what Shakespeare wrote! Juliet was supposed to be so much younger than she is in this (but, again, to make this fit with present day, someone of marrying age needed to be used), and the love is between two young people who are just learning what love really is. <br /> <br />I love the film. I think the soundtrack and the setting work well together, giving a 1990's feel to the story, but Luhrmann's attention to phrasing, to detail, amazes the watcher with its Shakespearean accuracy. <br /> <br />The move is worth an open mind, if nothing else. Even for those who don't \\"get\\" Shakespeare, or maybe especially for them, this is a way to appreciate his story without a freshman English teacher or a lot of confusion.

B0000DDAU9|5.0|Before the romanticists of primitivism came along, Thomas Hobbes' creed made life in the state of nature out to be something like \\"continual fear and danger of violent death,\\" where man's existence was \\"nasty, brutish, and short.\\" Sort of like Mastodon! This album set them up to become to become the chiefs of mdoern American heavy metal. Make no mistake -- Mastodon may be a lean, mean sophisticated bunch of metallers, but the dominant feature is its dirty, blunt aggression. Nowhere on this album does Mastodon strive to show everyone how talented they are by using fancy clean vocals or prog-metal trickery. Music comes across in rumbling sheets of distortion, waves of crunch like a cacophony of splintering skulls. Polyrhythms of growling riffage and frantic drums is the course for the most part, but there are a few quieter instrumentals. These are the weakest parts of the disc. Yet the rough and tough songs shine, where Mastodon has the subtlety of their namesake's stampede and the primitive drive to smash skulls and gobble raw, dripping animal flesh ('cuz that's how cavemen are, y'know). azz-kicking American metal.

B000009HF2|5.0|frampton comes alive would definitely compete for the status.    Great tunes (rock 'n roll and ballads), fantastic fretwork, a great backup band and magical band/audience chemistry marks this live double album which after nearly 30 odd years of release has still managed to retain a hallowed status in the history of rock.     frampton was and is a very serious musician and you can tell it by the quality of music that he presents. the music on this show was drawn from the first few solo studio albums that frampton recorded and he is in fantastic form throughout.    'show me the way', 'baby i love your way' and 'do you feel ...' may be popular. but 'doobie wah', 'all i want ...', 'i'll give you money' and 'lines on my face' are just as good. plus a killer version of the stones 'jumpin jack flash'.    of special note is the frampton's virtuostic fretwork who along with blazing solos also uses the voice box to great effect.    great one of a kind album this!    this album defines the magical 70s!

There were a few dramatic shots, but it was for the good of the movie; we all can understand that. Just let the music and actors do their job of equaling it out. What I loved the most was how they've paid attention to the little details that just makes a difference in a shot: how they've kept capturing Macfadyen (Darcy) from a far angle, watching Lizzy; the servants and farm animals in the background; and the differentiation behind the make up and hair in each scenes to say that: Lizzy Bennett did love to walk. <br /> <br />Keira Knightley is a lovely actress who played her role magnificently, but to my idea, she could have been a little more into her character instead of letting the cameras do all of the work; nonetheless, she'd played well enough to convince us that she WAS a worthy Lizzy Bennett.  <br /> <br />Matthew Macfadyen gave me second thoughts about Colin Firth, who was my favorite Darcy, until now. Macfadyen is a charming actor (not to mention, a heartthrob, for some of the girls) on screen; who made the situation even worst by playing the tall, dark, handsome, and mysterious, Mr. Darcy. I was blown away by his talent of being so much in character that I WAS convinced that he WAS Mr. Darcy. When he proposed for the first time to Lizzy Bennett (Knightley) nearly everyone in the theater gasped; not only for his confession, but how he had said it. Now, at this point, I was falling out of my seat. <br /> <br />Those two, with the combination of the brilliant casting made the movie complete.  <br /> <br />You don't need to read the book to understand what the heck is going on; you don't need to know every details of the characters' life to like it; and you don't need to worry about any details to look for. Just enjoy this movie, for it will lift you away, keep you at the edge of your seats and your hearts will never cease to stop fluttering until two hours after the movie. Definitely a must see!

B000AADYRQ|3.0|This review is for those not yet familiar with Death Cab for Cutie. Good music but nothing to write home about. <br /> <br />Overall, this is very mellow pop, kinda Coldplay meets the Beatles. Unfortunately, much closer to Coldplay's average fare. Mid-tempo beats with sappy melancholy piano and vocals (reverb added for spacious sound). I have not paid too much attention to the lyrics, but from what I heard, it's mildly depressing stuff like this quote from the first track: \\"Sorrow drips into your heart through a pinhole\\" <br /> <br />The quality of the songs is very consistent: three stars throughout, and they all sound almost identical. This in itself is perhaps the most impressive quality of DCfC's music. They remind me of Enya -- once you heard one album, you heard them all. Except that Enya does have a few relatively memorable tracks here and there while these guys are super consistent. <br /> <br />The best song on this album is What Sarah Said. Apparently, other reviewers agree. Listen to that song first to make up your mind. <br /> <br />I know why Death Cab for Cutie sound like they need some Prozac: just like them, I am from Seattle, where it's gloomy and rainy most of the year. I bet the weather had something to do with their music. They obviously don't record in the summer since nobody would be stuck in a studio in the 90 sunny days of the year. That said, another Seattle fellow, Jimi Hendrix, puts DCfC to shame with his creativity and energy.

B00006I53S|4.0|I first bought the Canon EF 28-135mm f/3.5-5.6 IS USM Zoom Lens to use with my Canon 10D along with the [[ASIN:B00004THCZ Canon EF 75-300mm f/4-5.6 III USM telephoto zoom lens]].  About three years later I now have a Canon 20D and sold off the Canon EF 75-300mm f/4.5-5.6 USM for a better lens.  As for the Canon EF 28-135mm, I still have it and get plenty of use from it.<br /><br />This is not an L lens, but that is no reason to avoid this lens; no matter what level you shoot at.  The construction is sturdy and consists of 16 elements in 12 groups.  The focus type is the standard twist zoom, and permits for auto or manual focus depending on how the switch is set.<br /><br />The Canon EF 28-135mm lens is compact measuring 3.8 inches long and lightweight weighing in at about 1.2 lbs/540 g, and accepts 72mm filters. Since my other lenses accept 77mm filters, I use a [[ASIN:B0002E3WKO step-up adapter ring]] to limit the number of filters I have when I can. The f/stop ranges from 3.5 - 22 on the short focus range and 5.6-36 on the long with the f/5.6 starting at about 90mm.  The closest focusing distance is 20 in/50cm.  In addition, the lens has a USM drive mechanism for optimum AF performance, and the pulse control diaphragm (EMD) ensures precise aperture control.<br /><br />The IS system is composed of a pair of gyro sensors to detect vertical and horizontal motion and a microprocessor that compensates for it by shifting special lens elements in parallel with the perceived movement.  It is recommended that the IS be off when shooting on a tripod. I have used the IS on my [[ASIN:B00007E7IL Bogen 3231 professional monopod with deatchable legs]] successfully.  A monopod is not as stable as a tripod though, with or without the legs.  Using the IS, you can obtain sharp pictures two stops below where you normally would.  This is a huge advantage in dim light or places where flash is prohibited.  Just keep in mind, the IS attempts to eliminate camera movement, not the movement of the subject being photographed.<br /><br />A distance scale ring sits below the focus ring.  Turn the distance scale ring all the way to the left and you are set for low magnification close-up photography.  Turn it to the right and you are able to set for infinity compensating for changes in temperature as necessary.  The distance scale includes figures in red as an infrared index to use when shooting black and white infrared film.  Shooting infrared is not available on all cameras.  If this feature is a must, make sure this lens is compatible for infrared photography on your camera body.<br /><br />The Canon EF 28-135mm includes a 1 Year US Warranty and the front & rear lens caps.  The [[ASIN:B000Q6NSAM EW-78BII hood]] and [[ASIN:B00014K2W6 LP1116 soft lens pouch]] is sold separately.  Depending on your set-up, the case may not be that important, but get the hood as it will decrease lens flare and increase metering accuracy.  If you use filters, Canon recommends against stacking.<br /><br />As I add new lenses to my collection, this lens will probably be sold.  I don't see myself selling this lens in the next couple of years though.  Depending on what subject I am shooting, I get heavy use of this lens.  It is a great starter lens at a good starter price with plenty of versatility.<br /><br />Update:  Having come into some cash, I sold this lens May '06 and upgraded to the [[ASIN:B000AZ57M6 Canon EF 24-105mm f/4 L IS USM lens]].  The 24-105mm was not available when I originally wrote the review of the 28-135mm lens.  If the price difference isn't an obstacle, consider purchasing the 24-105mm instead.  Otherwise enjoy the 28-135mm lens.<br /><br />PROS:<br />A compact, lightweight standard IS zoom that can be a workhorse<br />Versatile landscape lens<br /><br />CONS:<br />Hood not includedotographed.    A distance scale ring sits below the focus ring.  Turn the distance scale ring all the way to the left and you are set for low magnification close-up photography.  Turn it to the right and you are able to set for infinity compensating for changes in temperature as necessary.  The distance scale includes figures in red as an infrared index to use when shooting black and white infrared film.  Shooting infrared is not available on all cameras.  If this feature is a must, make sure this lens is compatible for infrared photography on your camera body.    The Canon EF 28-135mm includes a 1 Year US Warranty and the front & rear lens caps.  The [[ASIN:B000Q6NSAM EW-78BII hood]] and [[ASIN:B00014K2W6 LP1116 soft lens pouch]] is sold separately.  Depending on your set-up, the case may not be that important, but get the hood as it will decrease lens flare and increase metering accuracy.  If you use filters, Canon recommends against stacking.    As I add new lenses to my collection, this lens will probably be sold.  I don't see myself selling this lens in the next couple of years though.  Depending on what subject I am shooting, I get heavy use of this lens.  It is a great starter lens at a good starter price with plenty of versatility.    Update:  Having come into some cash, I sold this lens May '06 and upgraded to the [[ASIN:B000AZ57M6 Canon EF 24-105mm f/4 L IS USM lens]].  The 24-105mm was not available when I originally wrote the review of the 28-135mm lens.  If the price difference isn't an obstacle, consider purchasing the 24-105mm instead.  Otherwise enjoy the 28-135mm lens.      PROS:  A compact, lightweight standard IS zoom that can be a workhorse  Versatile landscape lens    CONS:  Hood not included

B000BMSTMS|5.0|Pop the CD in and press \\"Play\\" - you'll be amazed with the first 60 seconds of the introduction of Korn's new \\"See You On The Other Side\\" album. This album, besides refining the band, after going through a very rough time after loosing one of it's pioneer members, it shows a musical innovation between each song in this album....something you've never heard from Korn before. And who says innovation is not a good thing? Can be risky, but also rewarding if the right move is played. The album starts with a song with a very funky, industrial sound, a sound that is new for Korn. The track, \\"Twisted Transister\\" (first single) really outlines the above description Very well.  <br /> <br />In this album, you will find true feelings, a magnified sentiment towards our current social experiences, which include politics (also a track name), sex, and religion. I like a band that expresses truth and original feelings through a song.Korn have done it before, and they've done it again with this album. Korn is one of the very very few bands that we currently have that really mean something, because they play real music, with real feelings behind the music. What a great way to get back on the road with this album, on the path of what they do best: Music. Songs like \\"Politics,\\"\\"Hypocrites,\\"\\"10 Or A 2-Way,\\" and \\"Love Song\\" are definitely the introduction of this new  <br />'electro-industrial' sound Korn adopted in this album. Jonathan Davis unveils his vocals/lyrics as bold and affirmative in each of these songs, giving also a wide open space to the drumming and harsh, sometimes funky guitar riffs that James \\"Munky\\" Shaffer abruptly throws in several songs. The guitar work is remarkable, considering that Munky, for the first time, did all the guitar work himself! Speaking about guitars, what a great treat for us guitar lovers and admirers of this band with track \\"Open Up.\\" Not only did it give us a new dimension of what Korn can do musically, but also, for the first time, an exquisiteacustic guitar is heard, followed by always well-received bag pipes, single drumming and scab. Amazing!  <br /> <br />\\"Souvenir,\\"\\"Coming Undone,\\"\\"Liar\\"\\"For No One,\\" (song where Fieldy stands out more with his well recognized bass slapping)  <br />and \\"Eaten Up Inside\\" (bonus from the Deluxe CD Edition, which you should buy, and where David's drum work is absolute killer!) are tracks that remind us why Korn are the band that they are now. A band that keeps a real, unique sound and, regardless of any new added sounds to their work, they keep the Korn touch that has added this band in our music history books as a 'one and only' in their genre. I am pleased with this new album, the songs are so original and different from one another, it makes it difficult to select 'one' favorite one. Get this album, I fully recommend this album, you'll be surprised of the outstanding job Korn has done. To close, the band treated us(sentimental freaks) with \\"Tearjerker\\" a very mellow, inner-feeling melody that surprised everyone. Jonathan's voice is, unexpectedly, making me release a melancholic sigh, followed with chills! Amazing work, I can't say how much I love this album. Korn at its finest, indeed!

0553801503|4.0|As many reviewers have stated (but many more have ignored), this was a great book. The writing is excellent, and the set-up is masterly. All of the different elements of the plot are coming together, promising a collision greater than any we've seen in the previous three books. Whatever happens next (or at least, after Dance of Dragons), is going to be something to read. <br /> <br />But there's realy no avoiding it- although Martin's ability has only improved, it was unavoidable that this book would not carry the suspense and action that Martin's readers are so accostomed to. The point of Feast for Crows was really to tie up some of the loose ends of the last book, to let us know what's been changing in the character's lives between the war that was and the war to come, while setting up the players and the stakes for the next conflict. 700 pages of a lull in the story (even a lull that involves as many new characters and new plots as this one) is simply not going to hold up next to three books of action, plots, and mysteries that do come to fruition.  <br /> <br />But Martin didn't really have a choice, did he? Technically, he could have begun the next installment a few years later, and brought us up to date with the happenings of the characters in the first few chapters. Most of his fans would have complained then, too, but more rightly so. Instead, Martin chose to give his fans what they deserve for reading several thousand page books just to follow his story. He trusts us to stay on board while he tells a few seperate stories and sets up a few new ones, and gives us the opportunity to get to see the reasons and flaws and psycology behind the decisions that the characters make, instead of just the events themselves. <br /> <br />Of course, I prefer the story when all the characters are there, and their many different stories are slowly woven together as the plot advances, and used to give the readers new revelations and open new mysteries. I hope that the books after Dance of Dragons won't be split apart like this, and I am not sure if Dance of Dragons will have more plot, or if it will be similar to this book. <br /> <br />But this was an excellent novel, and while not as fast paced as the others, it does offer many opportunities to really examine the characters. The end of the book promises a lot of excitement in the next few books.

0876855575|5.0|I've only read two Bukowski books, this and Post Office. After Post Office I was impressed, because Bukowski revealed some v. interesting, funny stories about his job (in ways that todays \\"Waiting\\" and other career novels/movies do) and the short chapters made it an easy read. However, after looking up on Amazon what I should read next - it was obvious - Ham on Rye.  <br />It's the book that Holden Caulfield may have written if he had written an autobiography at the age of 50. The way he writes is shooting from the hip - no crap, just as he sees it; even if it means he becomes humiliating in the process. It also makes you realise why Bukoswki was such a bittered and twisted man - and why he turned to drink.  <br />Ham on Rye chronicles \\"Bukoswki\\" or, his alter-ego Henry Chinaski, through his first memories, living with an abusive father, through school, where he is an outsider, and into the world of employment - where he see glimpses of Post Office and what is yet to come for Chinaski. It ends when he is in his early twenties.  <br />If you are interested in how artists find their passion, how human beings can be so cruel, how we are our childhoods - then you will love this book. If you have ever felt alone, and wondered if anyone in the world really cares - then this books for you. - Just a warning, Bukoswki isn't an optimist - the exact opposite, some times you may cringe with how depressing he is. But that is why he was such a inovative writer, just like Salinger before him; he didn't believe in hiding his readers from the big bad scary world - he introduced them to it.
B0000009S3|5.0|Though he's better known as an extraordinary satirist, Zappa was also a guitar virtuoso and a briliant composer.<br />Let's face it, Frank Zappa's so-called \\"arty\\" contemporaries couldn't match Zappa. I mean, was Pink Floyd making use of countermelodies? Could ELP ever ditc the pretention and come up with a melody that will stick with you for days? Did the Beatles (or Led Zeppelin, for that matter) have enough talent to keep a group jam going for seventeen minutes? And were any of these groups as wonderfully eccentric as Zappa? No, no, no, and no.<br />Zappa couldn't have picked a better way to open this album than with Peaches En Regallia, an extremely innovative instrumental that will stick with you for the rest of your life. It never, ever gets old. Trust me. Believe it or not, his guitar takes a backseat to Mr. Ian Underwood's sax, clarinet and keyboard. Then we have Willie the Pimp. At first, it sounds like Zappa-by-numbers, with some sleazy lyrics from Captain Beefheart. But then Frank takes over on guitar, delivering a jaw-dropping seven minute solo. Brilliance. Thirdly is another group jam, Son of Mr. Green Genes, though with its' similar melody and feel it could have very well been called Son of Peaches En Regallia. As we'd expect, it's a highlight, with Zappa contributing a great melody and better guitar. I don't really have much to say about Little Umbrellas, which is fun but forgettable...<br />...especially compared to The Gumbo Variations, a seventeen-minute group jam that proves just what Zappa's group was capable of. Other bands can't keep a jam going for half this length - not even Santana. But Frank Zappa, Ian Underwood and violinist Sugarcane Harris actually sound like a jazz group, not a garage band playing as long as possible. It's awesome. Sadly, the closer (It Must Be a Camel) is weak.<br />So, there you have it. Good jazz from a famed rock musician. Yes, that is possible.

B00005NTJM|4.0|You'd never believe it, but Jethro Tull used to be a blues band. So before they were singing about Aqualung, the Minstrel in the Gallery, and Ray Lomas, they were playing the blues. As it turns out, they were a pretty good blues band, though this definetly can't be compared with Aqualung, Thick as a Brick, Minstrel in the Gallery, etc.<br /><br />Okay, we've got a good opener with the hangover-song My Sunday Feeling, and a couple nice original blueses, with Someday the Sun Won't Shine For You (Great title!) and Beggar's Farm. Well...it contains four of the flat-out WORST songs ever to appear on a Tull album. First, there's the resident endless boring instrumental known as Serenade to a Cuckoo. After that, another poor instrumental - Dharma For One (the ten-minute version on the outtakes album is good, though). It's Breaking Me Up...Zzzzzzzzz...Finally, Round. Awful. Another little issue I have with this album is that the flute playing isn't up to Anderson's usual standard, but that can be forgiven. After all, he had only learned how to play the flute recently. Though it's not their best album, it's worth seeking out. But not before you've lapped up every last bit of Aqualung, Thick As a Brick, Minstrel in the Gallery, A Passion Play and Benefit.

The song is fairly slow though, but it has some really heavy parts in it.  <br /> <br />7. Love Song - It starts out with a nice munky riff with some cool effects on it, has great synth work in this song rtight from the begining, again very manson-esque. The vocals are very angry, and this is a very refreshing song to listen to.  <br /> <br />8. This song starts out with some tradition KoRn slap bass and awesome drum beats. You gotta hand it to fieldy and david for this track. When munky kicks in everything just gets better though. This song sounds like it should be the next single, if hypocrites or politics are not. This one seems fairly depressing and angry, which is exactly what KoRn are famous for ( jokes ).  <br /> <br />9. Coming Undone - Starts out with a nice heavy, extremely distorted, riff. This is a fairly traditional sound song for KoRn though guitar-wise, but david's drumming sounds completely different from anything else he has ever done for the band before. The song is all-around cool, with a good mixture of new KoRn and old KoRn in it.  <br /> <br />10. Getting Off - It starts out with a heavy riff again by Munky with some cool effects in the background. The chorus sounds familiar though. Jon sings ' getting off, im getting off, keep getting off, keep getting off, im getting off, im getting off to you \\" and any hardcore KoRn fan will be remind of the song sean olson where jon screams \\" im cumming im cumming im cumming on you  \\". The vocals are superb on this track though. They are fit the song so tightly that it is a wonder about how jon does this stuff.  <br /> <br />11. Liar - Another traditional KoRn riff for the intro... Until the effects kick in. This song is obviously about... Head. The song is heavy through and through, and very angry.  <br /> <br />12. For No one- This song is very empowering but strange. It starts out heavy and fast, chills out for a few moments, and kicks back in and out again. The chorus is very heavy guitar-wise and jd dragsd the vocals on for, which does fit the song. This song also has great bass and percussion in it.  <br /> <br />Seen It All - Starts out slow, very slow, with a siren-like sound ( most likely an armonica ). This song is definitely their most unique song ever, with multiple instruments in it ranging from the armonica to bagpipes. This song doesnt have a manson-esque feel or a NIN-esque feel, but it sounds like this is a song that would inspire an industrial band. Everything from the vocals to the instruments are different from anything else KoRn has ever done. The outro is very long and instrumental, but fits the song well.  <br /> <br />14. Tearjerker - The title is self-explanatory. It is a great, slow, sad song. What else is there to say?  <br /> <br />I definitely suggest buying this album if you like KoRn, Industrial, Manson, System of a Down, or Alternative Metal at all. If i was allowed to i would give this album a 10 out of 5 stars, but sadly it doesnt let you.

0300108834|5.0|At the time this book was written (early 20th century), very few Westerners were properly informed about Asian and Middle Eastern history. Reading this book to one's child is an excellent opportunity to point that out and to ask him/her the question: what good is a well-written history book, if some of the information is wrong? Your child will surprise you with the creativity of his/her answer.    No book or system of education gets all the facts straight (news flash to American elementary school teachers -- Columbus did NOT sail west to prove the world is round! People already knew that).     You can't shelter your child from disinformation but you can teach her/him to think critically and to look for the truth her/himself. When the child is older, you can talk about primary sources and other tools good historians use to increase the accuracy of their work.    There's no law saying you have to read this book to your child in its entirety. You can be honest and say that as wonderful as the book is, people now know that the parts on the East are incorrect so you'll be skipping those chapters.    The introduction to the Italian Renaissance alone is worth the price of the book. Why entirely eschew a work that could get your young one excited about the history of the world?

B00005JO04|3.0|In Stephan Gaghan's screenplay for \\"Traffic\\" the prize was drugs, in \\"Syriana\\" everyone is after oil. The characters are the same only the names have changed. These people are cunning and ruthless. They care about no one but themselves.<br /><br /> The same day this movie came out I read an article in the New York Times stating \\" Americans do not trust business or the people who run it.\\" \\"Syriana\\" will not help their cause.<br /><br /> The movie is a complicated one. We follow a group of people, some who know each other, some who don't, who all seems to affect the other's life. This is the kind of movie you should know nothing  about. Don't worry about the plot, don't read the critics. In fact, I'd prefer you don't read this until you've seen the movie. To give you the slightest bit of information is to give away too much. The film should catch you by surprise and unfold before your eyes. That is the only real way to come to care about any of these characters.<br /><br /> As with \\"Good Night, And Good Luck\\" (another film I recommend you see) some people will accuse this movie of being Liberal. With \\"Good Night\\" I was willing to let the remark slide but this time I'm going to have to fight back against the Conservative Elite. \\"Syriana\\" is not offering left-wing talking points, nor is it offering right-wing. The movie doesn't take sides. As with the film \\"Traffic\\" (which I always felt deserved the Oscar over \\"Gladiator\\") both films look at a problem and try to deal with it in the most realistic way possible but never offer a solution. To offer a solution means the problem will go away, both films deal with topics so big there are no easy solutions.<br /><br /> \\"Syriana\\" opens in time for the big Oscar campaigns, the time when Hollywood saves its good movies. I could definitely see a few Oscar nominations coming this film's way. It would please me greatly if Christopher Plumber were to receive an Oscar nomination for \\"Best Supporting Actor\\" and Gaghan for \\"Best Screenplay\\".<br /><br /> And what about George Clooney? This seems to be his year. First writing and directing the exceptional \\"Good Night, And Good Luck\\" and now giving quite a powerful performance here. Clooney has managed to turn me into a fan.<br /><br /> But there are some things about this film I didn't like. I didn't care for the editing. I found a few shots unnecessary and at times disliked the cinematography. I feel the biggest downfall of the film though is we never get to really understand these people. Their concerns are never our concerns. Gaghan was able to accomplish this in \\"Traffic\\" and other emsemble films released this year also succeeding in doing so, \\"Crash\\" for instance, but \\"Syriana\\" takes on so much, many times the viewer feels overwhelmed. We feel we are missing something. We are playing a game of catch up and this becomes distracting.<br /><br /> Still despite everything \\"Syriana\\" is nicely crafted, expertly directed and well acted. Amanda Peet gives her best performance. I realize going over her credits that's not saying much, but it doesn't make the statement any less true. Some moments in this film are truly great. They are highly emotional and real. And as for Gaghan himself this is a notch above his previous film \\"Abandon\\" but a step beneath \\"Traffic\\", still it shows a great deal of promise for things to come. Which is more than we can say about some of the characters in this movie.<br /><br /> Bottom-line: Ambitious, grand-scale film that has some truly wonderful moments. The cast has moments where they shine but the film is too complex to really follow. There is no real understanding of these people still the movie is worth your time.Clooney? I found a few shots unnecessary and at times disliked the cinematography. I feel the biggest downfall of the film though is we never get to really understand these people. 0553288105|5.0|Clearly one of the true masters of science fiction, nobody ever blended the science and the fiction as well and as harmoniously as Isaac Asimov did. Asimov's speculations, though wild and far-fetched, always had their roots firmly in proven science, and thus his work is speculative fiction at its best; at the same time, the drama and characters are as solid as the basic theories, and the two elements melt together perfectly to create truly great science fiction. 'The Gods Themselves', one of the best of Asimov's works that stand on their own and not as part of a series, is a fantastic example of this talent. The novel makes a wild hypothesis that entices fascinating moral and philosophical dilemmas, and tries to work these out, never for a minute ceasing to be an enticing and engaging work of fiction. <br /> <br />'The Gods Themselves' addresses the dilemma from three different angles through the telling of three entirely separate stories, taking place in very different locations - one on earth, one in a parallel universe, and one in a human colony on the moon. While the tales are separate, they intertwine in a fascinating fashion. The novel's biggest flaw is probably the fact that the last part is doubtlessly the weakest. Though it does an excellent and masterful job of describing a human society adapted to life on a different world, it often loses its dramatic focus in favor of those descriptions and in descriptions of sex and nudity that are sometimes necessary and sometimes superfluous. <br /> <br />Be that as it may - the second part, taking place in the so-called Para-Universe, a universe parallel to our own and inhibited by an entirely different species than ours - is so good that in itself it makes the novel one of Asimov's greatest masterpieces. Asimov manages to create an entirely convincing alien race - a three-sexed alien race, complete with mating and reproduction proceedings - with minimum visual description of the universe or its inhabitants. Asimov manages the impossible here - the entire chapter is told from the aliens' point of view, and therefore the rituals and lifestyles that aren't in any way similar to anything we know is given minimal description, the entirely alien ideas being considered obvious and clear; and yet the master manages to give us a perfect idea of the way these creatures behave and act, making the reader believe in them as true characters with feelings and motives, even sympathize with them. This is such a huge achievement that in itself it makes 'The God Themselves' one of the true great masterpieces of science fiction. For any fan of the genre, not to mention any fan of Asimov's, this is a unique and essential masterpiece.

One might presume that the kind of audience that would turn up at a GB concert would surely be relaxed and relatively subdued, appreciating his playing and listening to him because they are just as cool as he is. No? <br /> <br />Evidently not! Well, not in this case at least. There is only one reason why I will never watch this concert again, and that is the audience. The feeling of extreme discomfort demonstrated by his facial expression is almost unbearable to watch. I might have been able to deal with it if she hadn't stayed up there for such a seemingly long time. I seem to recall that she mysteriously disappeared off the stage at the cut of a shot (...security?). However, I do not want to varify this, as it would mean that I'd have to watch it again. I can understand the way the audience would have felt that night, and I can understand the the urge to dance to the music. But I do feel that the way in which some people took part was quite unnecessary.  <br /> <br />Overall, George performs extremely well, as do the other musicians seen and heard here, but I won't be watching it again until they release a version taken only from the cameras pointed on the stage.

B000002UJQ|5.0|Wow. Let me start this review by saying this is one of the few \\"perfect albums\\" out there. It really is, and that's no overstatement. This, Radiohead's third, is a true masterpiece and will probably be ripped off for years to come, (COLDPLAY) even though some claim the music is inaccessible. I kept hearing the name of the group in conjunction with the Beatles, so I decided, \\"Why not try it out?\\" I first listened to Pablo Honey, which was pretty much standard Britpop. I have not had the pleasure of listening to The Bends, their sophomore album. But enough about me. Let's get into the music. \\"Airbag,\\" the opener, has one of the most dramatic opening riffs in recent memory. And add the almost cinematic sweeps of the rythm section, and you could listen to this song over and over. The next song, \\"Paranoid Android,\\" doesn't disappoint. It's a three-part story that could roughly be the life of a character from \\"Hitchhiker's guide to the Galaxy.\\" Defining moments are Jonny Greenwood's face-melting solos towards the middle and the end. Next come Subterranean Homesick Alien and Exit Music (For a Film). Both are highly interesting, while one is slow and loungesque, the other is chilling and haunting. The next two, Let Down and Karma Police, are \\"rockers\\" (though the first is somewhat slower) in the signature Radiohead style. Thom Yorke sounds superb on both  Then comes an interesting one. \\"Fitter Happier\\" is, in my eyes, the dividing line between the two \\"parts\\" (Although not a \\"true\\" concept album, OK Computer has qualities that make it such, but is not \\"divided\\" in two.) The spoken word song, which was made using a Mac's \\"Macintalk\\" setting, is basically a representation of the ideal \\"modern life,\\" a theme of the album. <br />   Electioneering kicks off the second half, a kind of wake-up call against the surreal imagery of \\"Fitter Happier\\" that could be sung from a politician or businessman's point of view. (It's Just Business!) Then comes the haunting \\"Climbing Up the Walls,\\" written by Thom Yorke as a result of his experiences working in a mental hospital. A truly creepy song. Then comes the beautiful \\"No Surprises,\\" which conflicts with the distubing \\"Walls.\\" It's impossibly simle, yet charming. The last two, \\"Lucky\\" and \\"The Tourist\\" are both slow, and share the theme of starting over again. And thus ends one of the great albums of our times, one that can be interpreted any which way you please.

0679423001|5.0|The first time I read Brideshead I thought it was only an alcholism story. Waugh did an incredible job of describing what it's like to love someone who is hooked on booze. Charles Ryder is best friends with Lord Sebastion Flyte, a golden young man who has everything but deststroys himself via the bottle. The scenes where Sebastion is happy and the scenes where he's drunk are intense and very realistic. The whole family is touched by his alcoholism and the whole family is hurt by it. Later Charles has a fairly dull romance with Sebastion's sister Julia but it serves to keep him involved in this intresting family so it's tolerable.  <br /> <br />Later, when I grew up I realized that Brideshead is also about religion, duty, and England. Which ever angle you choose to \\"come at\\" Brideshead doesn't matter. Evelyn Waugh, for all his faults was a dazzling writer and this is an unforgettable tale.

B000BJS4BM|5.0|22 years after she first graced the dance floor, Madonna is sending you an invitation to get into the groove again. And if Confessions is anything to go by, she shows the world that she still can dance as well as inspire.<br /><br />Working with her new partners, most notably the savvy Stuart Price, Confessions is a 12-track segued mix of dance ecstasy. Lead single, Hung Up, amazingly mixes Abba's 1979 hit Gimme Gimme Gimme (A Man After Midnight) with Madonna's and Price's retro-disco fluffiness into a bona fide dance floor anthem. Follow this with the throbs of the electro-futuristic Get Together where Madonna makes you check it out with her as she really wants to be with you. Then, the song fades cleverly into Madonna saying sorry in a few languages before she sends you to gyrate along with Sorry. On Forbidden Love, Madonna morphs into Giorgio Moroder and creates a superb 80s-sounding yet stylish song of two star-crossed lovers. On the Indian-inspired, beats-driven Push, Madonna pays tribute to the one (presumably Guy Ritchie)who has constantly pushed her to her best.<br /><br />On Confessions, Madonna's lyrics are never overly self-indulgent though short of any major revelations that we don't already know. There are self-discovery, enlightenment, empowerment, love, and lament.<br /><br />Confessions is a true return to form for the Queen of Pop, something all fans have been eagerly waiting for.<br /><br />The expanded version includes a 13th track Fighting Spirit, an electronic dance track with an uplifting message. Other goodies include a journal book with selected entries by Madonna, a picture book and 1-month trial membership to ICON, Madonna's fanclub. This is by far, the best Madonna special edition.<br /><br />For fans only.

B000BTJDGC|5.0|We're all dogged by our own little demons that cast doubt, shake our faith in ourselves and pull apart our world. However unlike the character of Emily Rose in this thought provoking drama none of our demons are named Lucifer. \\"The Exorcism of Emily Rose\\" tackles the issue of faith, how science has displaced our belief system rationalizing everything around us and pulled us out of the psychological barbaric dark ages. The film dares to ask, what if our rational side is wrong? What if there are supernatural forces beyond our comprehension which drive the world around us every day? A compelling tale that mixes fact (the film is based on the true story of Anneliese Michel documented by Dr. Felicitas Goodman in the book \\"The Exorcism of Anneliese Michel\\") with the format of a suspense thriller, court room drama and delves into the place of faith and reason in our society. I've seen many people disappointed by the fact that this isn't \\"The Exorcist\\". This is a suspense drama NOT a horror film like \\"The Exorcist\\". The exorcism itself isn't the focus of this movie but, instead, a sidebar. This is really about the after effects of what happens to Father Moore and Erin.<br /><br />Laura Linney plays defense attorney Erin Bruner an agnostic gun for hire that recently won a highly publicized murder trial. When the head of her firm (Colm Feore) asks her to take on a case for the Catholic Church involving a priest Father Moore (Tom Wilinson) accused of negligent homicide of Emily Rose (Jennifer Carpenter) she finds her disbelief melting as she's drawn further and further into the case. It seems that Emily, her family and Father Moore believe that she was possessed by the Devil. The prosecutor Ethan Thomas (Campbell Scott) is a man of strong religious beliefs who finds himself convinced that the girl was an undiagnosed epileptic who died because she was denied nutrition, medical help and the medication to control her seizures. This collision of church and state creates more than sparks as Erin discovers disturbing evidence that Father Moore may be right. She's further disturbed when strange things begin to occur to her just as they did to Emily and to Father Moore after the death of Emily. A warning though to fans expecting gore galore--this isn't your typical horror film like \\"The Devil's Rejects\\" or \\"The Texas Chainsaw Massacre\\". Instead, it's more of a suspense thriller using elements of the horror genre.<br /><br />A thought provoking film filled with intelligent performances, some genuinely scary sequences and many unanswered questions, \\"The Exorcism of Emily Rose\\" may come across as a bit too pat at its conclusion but the ride itself makes the film worth it. This unrated version runs about 3 minutes longer than the theatrical version.<br /><br /> \\"Exorcism\\" doesn't have the heavenly glow of the many brightly colored epics and comic book films we've seen this year and that works to the film's advantage. Filled with moody cinematography, striking images and plenty of mystic fog the transfer looks very good. There are some minor issues with compression particularly during one sequence involving heavy fog but, on the whole, the film captures the stark and scary look of its theatrical debut. The 5.1 Dolby Digital Surround soundtrack becomes genuinely spooky during many of the scenes involving Emily and Father Moore but the more tense court room scenes come across as much more passive involving only the ambience of the court. That stark contrast between these two worlds and experiences make the scenes involving Emily's \\"breakdown\\" and exorcism all the more riveting.<br /><br />We get a featurette that examines the history of the film and how the real event inspired the filmmakers to tackle such a daunting project with such an unusually intelligent approach. There's also a featurette that focuses on the visual approach for the film this is interesting as the director is, essentially, telling two different stories from two different points ofview. As I mentioned before very few films have balanced the thriller aspects with those looking at the role of faith in our society and \\"Exorcism\\", like \\"The Exorcist\\", manages to transcend the limitations of the genre. We also get a single deleted scene that, although important from a character development point of view, clearly would have slowed the narrative down and was wisely extracted.<br /><br />The commentary by director/co-writer Scott Derrickson focuses on many aspects of the production from the elements they borrowed from the real case to those of performance and integrating visual effects into the film in a believable fashion. The latter was missing from both \\"Dominion\\" and \\"The Exorcist: The Beginning\\" and, hence, undermined both those films from becoming little more than a footnote in the suspense/thriller/horror genre. In many respects, Derrickson's film acts almost as a \\"sequel\\" to \\"The Exorcist\\" (as that film was also based on a real life exorcism they share an incident that occurred as the basis of their projects). Derrickson's comments are intelligent and thoughtful about the project and the challenges he and his cast faced in making the story both compelling and believable.<br /><br />The unrated version (which is the version I saw)doesn't appear to me to feature any more gore than the theatrical version. My guess is that it features scenes that run just a tad bit longer but weren't included in the theatrical version. While the film sputters a bit by the time of the conclusion, the two hour journey was still more than worthwhile. A warning though to fans expecting gore galore--this isn't your typical horror film like \\"The Devil's Rejects\\" or \\"The Texas Chainsaw Massacre\\". The film manages to combine elements of \\"The Exorcist\\" and shows like \\"Law & Order\\" into a compelling mix all its own. Drawn into the darkness that consumes Emily both Father Moore and Erin are changed forever by their experience.view. As I mentioned before very few films have balanced the thriller aspects with those looking at the role of faith in our society and \\"Exorcism\\", like \\"The Exorcist\\", manages to transcend the limitations of the genre. We also get a single deleted scene that, although important from a character development point of view, clearly would have slowed the narrative down and was wisely extracted.<br /><br />The commentary by director/co-writer Scott Derrickson focuses on many aspects of the production from the elements they borrowed from the real case to those of performance and integrating visual effects into the film in a believable fashion. The latter was missing from both \\"Dominion\\" and \\"The Exorcist: The Beginning\\" and, hence, undermined both those films from becoming little more than a footnote in the suspense/thriller/horror genre. In many respects, Derrickson's film acts almost as a \\"sequel\\" to \\"The Exorcist\\" (as that film was also based on a real life exorcism they share an incident that occurred as the basis of their projects). Derrickson's comments are intelligent and thoughtful about the project and the challenges he and his cast faced in making the story both compelling and believable.<br /><br />The unrated version (which is the version I saw)doesn't appear to me to feature any more gore than the theatrical version. 0307263118|4.0|The Sea is a work of superb artistry, but this doesn't become clear until you're well into the book.<br /><br />The story in told in the first person by Max Morden, an art critic of no great reputation, whose wife, Anna, has recently died of cancer.  In his grief, Max flees to the small seaside town where as a boy he summered with his parents.  He deliberately puts up at the same boarding house where his childhood friends, the Graces, used to stay.  In the first part of the book, Max tries to articulate how he feels about Anna's death and slowly unfolds the tale of his youthful entanglements with the Grace twins, Chloe and Myles.<br /><br />Max comes across as a bit of a blowhard.  His verbal style is full of false bravado, rhetorical tics and bombastic pronouncements about loss and memory.  We're reminded again how fine writing, even prose as lush and well-wrought as Banville's, can obscure as well as illuminate.  As Part 1 builds to its somewhat overwrought climax, we're wondering what Max - and Banville - are on about.<br /><br />But in Part 2, the novel slows and deepens; in the process, what we've already read is seen in a new light.  Max's posturing and evasions are exactly what both he and Banville have been on about - the ways we construct and defend a self, and how inadequate those defenses are against the inevitable running down of the organism.  In Part 2, both Max and the author seem to be saying, \\"but enough of all that.\\"  When Max stops spinning defensive constructs, other truths have the opportunity to emerge.<br /><br />This being a Banville novel, it's never quite that simple, because Banville doesn't view the self as a fixed, immutable point.  Max tells us in a revealing passage, \\"... even the notion of an essential singular self is problematic.\\"  As a boy, Max loves to watch birds, especially to discover where they built their nests.  A Banville hero constructs the self the way a bird builds a nest, a random assembly of opportune scraps.  Like a nest, this self is something impromptu and temporary pretending to permanence.<br /><br />As Max digs deeper into his memories of the Graces, and especially his boyhood romance with the newly pubescent Chloe, he achieves a curious insight: the more concrete his memories get, the more manufactured they probably are.  We who have been taught that truth lies in particularity are brought to see that this same particularity is also the raw material for credible but false constructions.<br /><br />By the book's end, we learn what drove Max back to the haunts of his boyhood, and we see that he will emerge from the fog that surrounds those caught between the dead and the living.  He will go on, not because he wants to, particularly, but because he can.  Both the paradox and the triumph of this superbly realized work is that out of Max's posturing, out of his erratic manufacture of memories, emerges something as poignant, illuminating and half-grasped as truth itself.<br /><br />The book has other, smaller pleasures, such as the sensuousness of Banville's prose, his painterly eye for nature, and the precision with which he captures the intensity of what a child sees and feels.  The Sea richly deserves the Booker Prize it was awarded this year.  Few novels illuminate so well the torments and consolations of the modern consciousness.omptu and temporary pretending to permanence.     As Max digs deeper into his memories of the Graces, and especially his boyhood romance with the newly pubescent Chloe, he achieves a curious insight: the more concrete his memories get, the more manufactured they probably are.  We who have been taught that truth lies in particularity are brought to see that this same particularity is also the raw material for credible but false constructions.    By the book's end, we learn what drove Max back to the haunts of his boyhood, and we see that he will emerge from the fog that surrounds those caught between the dead and the living.  He will go on, not because he wants to, particularly, but because he can.  Both the paradox and the triumph of this superbly realized work is that out of Max's posturing, out of his erratic manufacture of memories, emerges something as poignant, illuminating and half-grasped as truth itself.     The book has other, smaller pleasures, such as the sensuousness of Banville's prose, his painterly eye for nature, and the precision with which he captures the intensity of what a child sees and feels.  The Sea richly deserves the Booker Prize it was awarded this year.  Few novels illuminate so well the torments and consolations of the modern consciousness.

Otherwise, the token girlfriends Faith Domergue and Ava Gardner are attractive but lacking the sizzle and exceptional beauty of either real-life woman.  But the real stunning disappointment was the appearance of Jean Harlow, and I didn't realize at first the person playing her was supposed to be Harlow, as this one was way too sophisticated and OLD.  Jean Harlow was a baby-face discovery as a teenager.  She was only in her mid-twenties when she died, and she was still an innocent looking baby-face when it happened.  That casting was truly bizarre considering the care and attention played to some of the other casting, as if for Harlow the director didn't even try to get it right.  Regards male co-stars, Alec Baldwin's talents are wasted here, he really has nothing to sink his teeth into, the same can be said for Alan Alda, who seems to specialize in playing politicians at this stage of his career; but there is a peculiar lightness to him which makes it impossible to believe he is ever a figure of substantial influence and power - just as well he is a bought man here. 0790732203|5.0|I remember as a 17 Yr old in 1983 seeing the commercials for Risky business on TV,rolling my eyes and thinking to myself\\"another one??\\"it seemed like every other week their was a new Teen-sex movie,and Risky Business seemed just as mindless as all the others,dont get me wrong,as much as I adored the Naked Female form,sitting through 80 minutes of drivel for 10 minutes of Flesh was no longer something My teenaged self could stomach.had it not been for a friend who invited me to the movies I would never have seen the film at all.I remember readying myself for another Porkys-Private School-Spring Break fiasco as the lights dimmed,within a few minutes of the movie starting however,with those images of the slowmoving trains,and that haunting Tangerine Dream score I realized that this was anything but a typical teen sex romp.I sat there for the next hour and a half mesmerized by the Arty Camera work,great cinematography,clever script,Rebecca DeMornays eyes,the\\"guido the killer pimp\\"line(which always got the biggest laugh),The eerie,Dreamlike tangerine Dream score,The clever soundtrack mixing contemporary 80s music(Prince,Talking Heads,the police)with Blues and Fusion(Muddy Waters,Jeff Beck)it was like an arthouse version of an 80s teen movie and I absolutey loved it!I went back and saw it 5 more times in the theatre and the following year a couple more times when it aired on cable.seeing it on DVD more then twenty years later,the movie is still very impressive,a true Cinematic Gem from that memorable decade although I wish it had included more extras,ESPECIALLY the alternate ending.What ive always wondered was why didnt paul Brickman,The Director,ascend to greatness after this Film,instead of not doing another Movie for over ten years??
0375703764|5.0|House of Leaves is a novel about a screenplay about a movie about a creepy house.  If that doesn't sound post-modern enough for you, the movie's protagonist ends up reading a novel called House of Leaves.  Although the house is very creepy indeed, I suspect that fans of horror novels will find the story less than terrifying. <br /> <br />On the other hand, people who enjoy books that interleave a scary and violent plot with lengthy digressions on highbrow academic topics will really get a kick out of this book.  In fact I'm fairly confident in saying it's the best of the genre.  You would think the market for this kind of thing would be quite small, but apparently the book was a best seller, so go figure. <br /> <br />Anyway, don't be put off by the zany layout of the text.  Part of the experiment that the author is undertaking is to convey the broad strokes of the plot by means other than the words themselves.  So for instance we have the main character crawling through a passage that grows smaller, all of which is described in text that occupies an increasingly restricted portion of the page.  Sound silly?  Maybe.  But it's not fair to say that the weirdness is gratuitous, and you certainly have to give the guy credit for creativity.  Personally, I found the book to be highly entertaining, and it definitely changed the way I think about my basement.
B000AP04FG|4.0|This movie seemed like \\"True Lies' meets \\"War of the Roses\\" meets \\"Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid\\".  I liked it and enjoyed the way it had fun with the whole ridiculous premise.  Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie hit the perfect balance of playing it straight, but not seriously.  It is an action comedy and a pretty darn good one.  Vince Vaughn adds a nice off beat touch to the whole thing.  Comparing his friendship with John Smith and Jane Smith's team, well, we can see clearly the difference not only in style but in personality.<br /><br />Look, it is hard to take professional killers seriously as people and especially ridiculous that such self-involved cold-hearted professionals appoach marriage as \\"what's it got for me\\" and wonder why their \\"relationship\\" has problems.  However, it does offer a kind of light commentary on 21st century dual professional marriages, doesn't it?<br /><br />Anyway, my advice is to enjoy the movie as fun and not make more of it than it is. B000002JSR|5.0|I truly LOVE this album, and I hold it in the same high regard as all the other Zep albums.  The fact that it's a compilation of rehearsals and spares is of no matter at all to me. However, I'm quite suprised that there was barely a mention of my personal favorite, the wildly wanton Walter's Walk!  This song is a playful blitzkreig, a thundering, kick-*** cannonade, which is physically impossible not to break out with air-instruments on (this includes me, a 40 year old female!). Poor Tom is a snappy little acoustic tale with an Old West feel.  I Can't Quit You Babe is a superb dress rehearsal that is more explosive than the smoldering Zep I version.  Ozone Baby and Darlene are bouncy, fun and they jam.  Bonzo's Montreaux is an instrumental that reminds you just why Zep couldn't continue without John.  Wearing & Tearing lashes out and grabs you by the figs from, literally, the first bone-crushing second and never lets go.  It's true Zep.  All four of our boys each get to show us their stuff in this album, and I thank God that it was compiled and released, so we could have the privilege to own this rip-roaringly good rock!!

They appear in bewildering scenes that don't seem to go together.  Was this a rush job?  Did the producers have sufficient funding?  Did left-wing ideology trump aesthetic concerns?  Could it be that too many chefs were in the proverbial kitchen?  How can so many talented people go so wrong?  I am giving Syriana three stars, but maybe two would be more appropriate.
B00004ZB9D|5.0|In the mid 1990s, I heard a concert promotion radio ad that was basically introducing the performer to be \\"The World's Greatest Rock and Roll Star\\".    When they announced that star to be Lenny Kravitz, I must admit, I nearly drove off the road when I heard that.    I had realized Kravitz had some commercial success and had a nice following, but \\"World's Greatest Rock and Roll Star\\"?  - Come On!  However, now about a decade later, as I have begun to get a deeper appreciation for what Rock music has to offer, I now realize that perhaps there is some real merit to that radio ad.    I'm still not ready to put Kravitz up there with the upper echelon of Rock with the Paul McCartneys, the Rolling Stones,  Bruce Springsteens, or even Billy Joels - however, it is safe to say that Kravitz could easily be one of the great revelations of the 1990s and has lived completely up to expectations as he has entered the 2000s.    In 2000, Kravitz amassed enough material and success to release his first Greatest Hits album.   This collection, \\"Lenny Kravitz Greatest Hits\\" provides some a great cross-section into Kravitz's musical career and is a great place to start if you are interested in checking out Kravtiz's material. <br /> <br />\\"Lenny Kravitz Greatest Hits\\" hits focuses on the first decade of Kravitz's career (1989-2000).   During this time, Kravtiz would release five solo albums for an average of 1 album every 2 years.     These albums (and the associated tracks included from these albums) are:  1989's \\"Let Love Rule\\" (\\"Mr Cab Driver\\", \\"Let Love Rule\\");  1991's \\"Mama Said\\" (\\"It Ain't Over Til It's Over\\", \\"Stand By My Woman\\", \\"Always On the Run\\");  1993's \\"Are You Gonna Go My Way\\" (\\"Are You Gonna Go My Way\\", \\"Heaven Help\\", \\"Believe\\"); 1995's \\"Circus\\" (\\"Rock and Roll is Dead\\", \\"Can't Get You Off My Mind\\");  \\"5\\" (\\"Fly Away\\", \\"I Belong to You\\", \\"Black Velveteen\\").    As with the case of most greatest hits albums, there is one new song to stimulate album sales among the deep fan base - a very solid song called, \\"Again\\".   It is worth noting that Kravitz's cover of the Guess Who's \\"American Woman\\" is also included on this collection.   This song was part of the soundtrack of \\"Austin Powers - The Spy Who Shagged Me\\", but was eventually included on the re-issue of \\"5\\".   One thing that is very nice about this collection is that it is split among the 5 albums just about evenly.   I'm pleased that there are even two songs from his first album which was really not commercially successful. <br /> <br />I think that Kravitz hits the three main dimensions that I expect from a successful solo artist:   Vocals,  Instrumentation, and Songwriting.    On top of these three dimensions, Kravitz cross all of these dimensions by providing a variety of different music styles.    Whether it is hard Rock,  R&B, or Funk - Kravitz finds ways to incorporate these styles and more into his music.  Kravitz was influenced by Prince who also incorporated similar styles into his music.   \\"Lenny Kravitz Greatest Hits\\" will show examples of this wide range of diversity.   You can hear Kravitz's Hard Rock style on \\"Are You Gonna Go My Way\\", \\"American Woman\\",  \\"Fly Away\\", \\"Rock and Roll is Dead\\" and \\"Always on the Run\\".   Songs such as \\"Mr Cab Driver\\" have a definite Funk influence in it - especially on the Bass.  Still songs such as \\"Heaven Help\\" , \\"It Ain't Over Til its Over\\", and \\"I Belong to You\\" show Kravitz' R&B side.   Despite these obvious influences, it is not easy to pigeon-hole Kravtiz's music into one musical genre.  There are many of his songs that definitely cross several of these genres and also break new ground.  Perhaps the best example of this is \\"Black Velveteen\\".   \\"Black Velveteen\\" has been a song that Kravitz has been criticized for, but I happen to think it's the best song he has done.    The song does have a \\"Euro Pop\\" feel, but it you will hear parts of Hard Rock and even R&B overlaid on top of this.  I like how Kravitz tries to do something \\"out of the box\\" and \\"different\\" to his music.     Kravitz's ability to innovate didn't happen late in his career - listen to his early song \\"Let Love Rule\\".  Kravitz uses combines some R&B with some Jimi Hendrix-like sounds to give a unique sound. <br /> <br />As mentioned I think it comes down to the three dimensions I list above.    Kravitz shows incredible range on his vocals - whether it's \\"It Ain't Over Til It's Over\\", \\"Let Love Rule\\" or his new track \\"Again\\", Kravitz will show he is not one dimensional as a vocalist.   From an instrumentation standpoint, Kravitz is well-known for his incredible guitar, but also listen to his Bass work as well.   You'll hear Kravitz incorporate other instruments as well - such as piano on \\"Heaven Help\\" or horns on \\"Let Love Rule\\" and \\"Always on the Run\\".      Lost in this whole picture is some of Kravitz's songwriting - this is perhaps one of the most overlooked dimensions of his talent.   Once again, this can even be traced early to his career - on 1989's \\"Mr Cab Driver\\", he describes the experiences of racism and discrimination. <br /> <br />There is one negative on this collection.  I normally like when an artist puts tracks in chronological order because this allows me to hear how the artist progressed over time.  Unfortunately, this collection does not do so.   It would have been a great strength if this had been done on this collection. <br /> <br />The liner notes include the lyrics to the new song - \\"Again\\".  The songwriting credits as well as what album the song is included on are also included in the liner notes.     Overall, this is as solid a Greatest Hits album as it gets.  The only other negative may be as Kravitz continues to have success, this album might someday be eclipsed by a more current Greatest Hits portfolio.
0064471047|5.0|The Chronicles of Narnia is one of the supreme treasures of all English literature--a wonder in childhood, at coming of age, in adulthood, and in old age.  It is also a bringer of hope and a force for good in a world where despair and evil are present and need resisting.  It is one of the best gifts you can give a child, a friend, or yourself. <br /> <br />You should definitely note, however, that the publisher of this and some other recent editions has made a moronic and despicable decision to change the order in which Lewis intended the books in the series to be read.  \\"The Lion, The Witch, And The Wardrobe\\" is the first book in The Chronicles, and the way Lewis intended his readers to first encounter Narnia.  \\"The Magician's Nephew,\\" the next-to-last book in the series as Lewis wrote it, is a sort of flashback in Narnia's history, and the events related in it take place earlier than those in \\"LWW\\" in a chronological sense.  IT IS IMPORTANT TO READ \\"THE LION, THE WITCH, AND THE WARDROBE\\" FIRST, AND TO READ \\"THE MAGICIAN'S NEPHEW\\" SIXTH, AS LEWIS INTENDED.  CHANGING THE ORDER CHANGES THE WHOLE TONE AND ATMOSPHERE OF THE STORY FOR THE WORSE.  Don't let the delusion of the publisher's staff that they somehow outrank C.S. Lewis in literary and artistic judgment rob you of the best possible experiencing of this masterpiece--READ LWW FIRST!
