B0000001PW|4.0|Corea and his band hit on some good song structures here as well as turn in some tasty solos to make for a better than average listening experience for fusion fans while avoiding the bland sounds of \\"smooth jazz\\".<br /><br />HIGHLIGHTS:<br /><br />Best track here for my money is \\"Got a Match?\\" as Chick Corea's multilayered keyboards soar over a solid walking bass line from John Patitucci. On \\"Sidewalk\\" it's probably Corea's Fairlight synth that gives the insistent bass pulse. \\"City Gate\\" isn't so much a separate song as it's the quiet prelude to \\"Rumble\\". It's aptly named...suggesting a street brawl rather than a Jets and Sharks Broadway-style dance fight. \\"Elektric City\\" resembles a theme song for a long-lost 80s cop show pilot. \\"King Cockroach\\" starts with interesting shifting percussion from Dave Weckl and also features frenetic Corea soloing. Weckl also is key to closer \\"Silver Temple\\" as his nimble cymbal work sets the pace before the track segues into more of a Scott Henderson guitar workout later on.<br /><br />LOWS:<br /><br />There's no \\"boogie\\" to be found on \\"Cool Weasel Boogie\\". It's one of the few here that I find boring.<br /><br />BOTTOM LINE:<br /><br />If you want to hear the fusion side of Corea's work in the 80s, this is a good choice. Recommended.
0064409422|3.0|3 stars is being generous; should be 2.5, really, overall, but out of sentimental value I bumped them up half a star. As a child, I absolutely loved the Narnia series and devoured all the books over and over again.     I recently went back and re-read them again, and to my deep disappointment, I could not feel that they held up; they did not age well. I found them preachy, condescending (remember Lewis describing all the evil creatures that attended Aslan's execution? \\"if I described them, your mother would not let you read this book\\"? oh, come ON), sexist (\\"battle is ugly when women fight\\" -- what, it's not ugly period?) and racist (recall the brown evil Calormenes and the fair good Narnians). As a longtime fan of Tolkien, I have to acknowledge that his work, too, is racist and sexist, but in his work it doesn't strike anywhere as strongly as in Lewis' work; it is not nearly as blatant. Also Narnia just feels shallow somehow. I read one reviewer describe Lewis as a magpie -- picking the shiniest mythological jewels with which to adorn his Narnia-nest, regardless of whether or not they match, and I have to agree. In addition, he has mere children going into bloody medieval battle -- recall Peter's one-on-one combat with King Miraz in Prince Caspian? -- without ever considering, realistically, the effects on a child of committing that kind of messy, sweaty, smelly, bloody slaughter. I know it's children's literature, but I don't feel it does children any favors to pretend ugliness isn't there when it is. You needn't spell it out in explicit detail, but at least don't pretend it ISN'T horrifying. That is not only dishonest, but dangerous.    Still, there are some very affecting passages. The scene at the end of \\"Prince Caspian\\" when Susan and Lucy go on their romp with Aslan is one of the best I've ever read, and who can help loving Mr. Tumnus or feeling a chill at the White Witch? Or weeping along with Lucy and Susan when Aslan is murdered, and then smiling in delight when he rises up again whole, joyous and strong? And then the best scene, in my opinion, of the whole series is when they arrive in Paradise in \\"The Last Battle\\" to find, to their shock, a Calormene devotee of the demon Tash there ahead of them. To him, Aslan says in effect, \\"Nothing good can be done to him, nor anything evil done to me, so when you did good in Tash's name, you were actually doing that good in service of me.\\" A startling and uplifting opinion for such a conservative Christian author to express, even in fiction! (And one I wish the fundamentalist Christian rightwing in the USA would pay more attention to.)    But I would recommend, if you want to read Lewis at his astounding best -- and it is astounding -- picking up a copy of \\"Till We Have Faces.\\" One of the best pieces of literature I have ever read, he deserves to be known for that rather than for his amusing but rather tepid Narnia series.

Italy is NOT romantic for those who live there. So, if you want to read about the \\"real\\" Italy, read e.g. \\"The Dark Heart of Italy: Travels Through Time and Space Across Italy\\" from Tobias Jones (available through Amazon ;-) and do not get yourself lulled by Grisham's superficial observations. <br /> <br />And how poorly he has researched the details! Terminal 2 in Malpensa airport is strictly charter, so no non-stop scheduled flights to Dulles from there, I am afraid. And by the way, there is not and was never a Lufthansa direct flight to Dulles from MXP. Why did Grisham not simply pick up a flight schedule?  <br /> <br />Train trip from Milano Centrale to Zrich: The first stop in Switzerland is always Chiasso, and not Belinzona. AND: There are very strict passport controls on all trains between Italy and Switzerland. Why did Grisham forget to mention that, especially since \\"Mario\\" was so worried about his false passport? 0140177396|5.0|Of Mice and Men follows two men in their pursuits through the Great Depression. One of the men, George, is the average quick-witted man.  His traveling partner, Lennie, is beyond kind and only has the best intentions in mind, but is mentally challenged and has an ogre-esque build.  He represents the innocence of man, but even though his intentions are for the best they often create trouble.  Lennie and George are in search of work, so they become ranch hands at a farm.  They desire the same dream as most Americans at this time, the American Dream.  They wish to own a small farm, work for themselves, raise animals, and \\"live off the fatta the land\\".  This novel follows two men in through evil, innocence, death, corruption, loneliness, companionship, strength and weakness. <br /> <br />America was founded on opportunity.  Early Americans emigrated from different countries for work, religion, freedom from war, and several other reasons.  The poverty stricken was in search of land and wealth.  George and Lennie only wanted to own a piece of land and \\"tend the rabbits\\".  All that mattered to them was being self sufficient and have the joys of life.  They were in search of opportunity, just as Americans are still in search of today.   <br />

B00006BSGZ|5.0|This is a conflation of two rare televised appearances of Callas from Covent Garden. The first was filmed in 1962 and Callas is in surprisingly good voice, considering she had almost given up at this time (her only other appearances that year were a series of concerts - no stage appearances at all). The Verdi is sung with a wealth of detail and expression and she acts out all Elisabetta'a emotions vividly, while hardly moving a muscle. Indeed she is so immersed in her singing that when a large brooch she is wearing dislodges and drops to the floor, she barely notices. She then changes completely into a playful, sexy and dangerous Carmen. What a pity she never wanted to sing the role on stage.<br /><br />The second part of the DVD is a fully staged performance of Act2 of Tosca with Tito Gobbi and Renato Cioni. Why oh why didn't they have the forseight to film the whole thing? Still I guess we should be grateful for what we have. There are faults - the camera work isn't all it should be - but this is surely the most riveting perofrmance of this act ever committed to film.True, Callas was in better voice when she filmed this same Act in Paris a few years previously (some of the top notes are little better than screams), but I have rarely, if ever, seen opera singers act with such naturalness and abandon. Both Callas and Gobbi are superb. You really forget they are singing and end up being totally drawn in to the performance of two actors. In fact I remember that on the days I worked at the English National Opera shop, whenever we played this video when the audience were gathering for that evening's performance, the tiny little shop would quickly fill up with people who couldn't take their eyes off the television screens. Enough said!
B0000029LG|4.0|This was my first ever set of Mijac's music and I immediately liked it. <br />   I only would like to discuss the second CD because it contains new music. <br />   SCREAM is the greatest song and video I ever experienced from Mijac. It's got a message, listen up!  <br /> <br />    GHOSTS is a great r&b song that is solid, consistent and you can easily get hooked on the melody. The video is awesome, too. I bet!  <br /> <br />    IS IT SCARY: brother of the previous one. Jackson's best vocal achievement since 1995's 'Smile' and before 2001's 'Unbreakable'. An r&b-based song that grows to a pop hymn - without a hymnical feature.  <br /> <br />    MORPHINE: This is I think MJ's most unique song ever, quite the 'Musicology' for him. This is fully composed & ordered by him, he even plays the instruments.  <br />The song mixes an acid and steely beat with innovative vocal elements of metal and even a Jackson-style rap. So a closed composition emerges.  <br />I hated Morphine first. But now I see it as a kind of masterpiece.  <br /> <br />    OK. Don't buy it. It's mess.  <br />But I bet you still do. Enjoy!

B000001G5H|5.0|I have bought most of the recent releases of Chopin's incredible studies, and I still believe that this recording comes closest to a pianistic ideal.  Pollini is stunning in his ability to convey the greatest depth and technical facility in these two transversals of Romantic piano technique and musical expression.  Some critics complain that Pollini is too cold to play this music, but I must completely disagree.  Because he does not attack the music in demented manner or disrupt the musical line for the sake of misguided \\"individuality\\" does not mean that Pollini is unable to project incredible range of this music's emotions. Of course, as a technician, Pollini has few if any who come close to his command of the keyboard. I have listened to Perahia's recording (special in many of the studies), Lugansky's (Second favorite after Pollini's), Gavrilov's, Askenazy's, Lortie's, and the list goes on. I have also studied some half dozen of these myself in the last half decade, and it is this recording that I view as being ideal interpretively and technically.  It is a must for anyone wishing to own a recording of the Chopin Etudes.

0553573403|3.0|There is something everyone who is thinking about reading this series should know, IT ISN'T YOUR TYPICAL FANTASY NOVEL. Is that a good thing, you ask? Well, maybe.<br /><br />****************************************<br /><br />You might like this book if . . .<br /><br />****************************************<br /><br />1. You would rather read about political manipulations than fighting and war-mongering.<br /><br />2. Very graphic sex scenes do not bother you.<br /><br />3. You do not require lots of magic in your stories.<br /><br />4. You enjoy well developed, detailed characters who tend to have fatal character flaws.<br /><br />5. You like a very long, very in-depth mystery<br /><br />6. You don't mind reading about the \\"grit\\" of medival life. Nothing is sugar coated here, rest assured of that.<br /><br />7. You don't mind not having a central character to root for.<br /><br />****************************************<br /><br />You will hate this book if . . .<br /><br />****************************************<br /><br />1. You expect a fantasy novel to have lots of fantasy in it.<br /><br />2. If 15 pages of action out of 200 is not ok with you.<br /><br />3. Very detailed sexual exploits offend you.<br /><br />4. You want to really care about a character or need someone to root for.<br /><br />5. You don't like really long stories (if an 800 page book makes you shudder, this one isn't for you because it only gets worse)<br /><br />6. Similar sounding names infuriate you.<br /><br />7. You don't mind keeping up with 8+ plot lines and 20+ major characters.<br /><br />*****Magic*****<br /><br />There isn't a whole lot of magic in this world. Especially when compared to something like Harry Potter in which everything up to, and including, the crapper is magical. Here is a list of just about everything magical I could find:<br /><br />1. Ancient tree spirits<br /><br />2. Ancient undead . . . things<br /><br />3. Extra long seasons. A typical round of seasons might look like this: summer lasts 7 years, fall last 3 years, winter last 5 years, spring last 4 years, summer last 4 years, fall last 6 years, etc.<br /><br />4. Children grow up faster. From the way the story is written (he never explicitly says one way or another) we can conclude that children reach maturity much sooner than \\"real\\" people do. So, a 15 year old boy is equal to a 18 or 19 year old \\"real\\" boy. Likewise a 13 year old girl is equal to a 16 or 17 year old \\"real\\" girl. It is a little odd but you get use to it.<br /><br />*****Characters*****<br /><br />Many of the characters are either stock, evil or borrowed from some other pieces of fiction. There are several who are \\"good\\", many who are \\"bad\\" and a handful whom are \\"indifferent\\". Yet, in spite of all of that it is easy believe that they are real. Martin does a good job of making them seem lifelife. So, even if you think you have seen them before they are still crafted nicely here. There aren't that many truly unique characters though and no one exists as \\"The Hero\\".<br /><br />*****Action*****<br /><br />Very limited action considering the amount of story telling that goes on. There is a tournament, a war, lots of brawling and the occasional fist fight. If you need lots of adventure go buy a comic book because this isn't for you.<br /><br />*****Plot*****<br /><br />This is a very plot driven story. The plot is interesting, don't get me wrong, but it can get a little tiring at points. Most of the time you will try and unravel the many mysterys laid before you and thus won't notice (too much) that the book is really long. Now, I am not against long books, provided there is a point to all that length. Writing just to fill space annoys me though. And while Martin is interesting, and descriptive, there are times when I think an editor should have gone though this thing a little harder than he originally did.<br /><br />So, overall, do I recomend this book? Sort of. If you can get past the lack of actionand magic then this isn't too bad of a book. Here is an interesting note, though. If Martin had taken out the 4 somewhat magical elements of this book, changed the setting to medieval Europe and modified a few names, then this could easily sit on the \\"Fictional History\\" shelf.though. If Martin had taken out the 4 somewhat magical elements of this book, changed the setting to medieval Europe and modified a few names, then this could easily sit on the \\"Fictional History\\" shelf.

0375507256|5.0|I started reading this book right after finishing Cunningham's recent Specimen Days. The two have several things in common, most obviously the interweaving of several separate stories into a (supposedly) larger whole. This kind of clever constructions are usually not my cup of tea (I share my misgivings about them with some of Mitchell's own characters) - far too often they merely mask a lack of sustained narrative invention. In fact I was deeply disappointed by the Cunningham, and thus approached this bulky novel with some trepidation. No need for that, as it turned out - on the contrary. This book is in a totally different league than Specimen Days. In fact, it is one of the most engrossing things I have read in a long time - the kind of book that makes you put out your bedside lamp far too late on weekday nights, and whose characters and themes mull about in your head while you are trying to work.<br /><br />Cloud Atlas consists of six separate stories, no less, which open up one out of the other, only to fold back in on themselves again in reverse order. \\"A gimmick?\\", the author himself wonders with supreme irony by mouth of composer Roger Frobisher, who is writing a sextet that is constructed in precisely the same way as this novel (with which it also shares the name). In this case, definitely not. The six stories are cleverly and meaningfully interwoven in a way that so eluded Cunningham in his similar attempt. Yet each on their own they are fully developed, unhurried, and in turn moving, inspiring and thrilling. They all center around the theme of the human will to power and domination, and the destruction inherent in it. Jalousie de m&eacute;tier, corporate corruption and greed, predatory survivalism, slavery, consumerism and whatnot drift in and out of focus as we cross the ages from the 19th century Pacific, via early 20th century Belgium, 70s California, and present-day Britain, to a horrific view of a future ruled by Asian corporations, and a future beyond that again when civilization has collapsed completely, but the saddening cycle of human inhumanity is starting all over again nonetheless. Mitchell's versatility of style and genre is dazzling to say the least. Cloud Atlas encompasses a diary, a correspondence, a kafkaesque farce, a racy thriller, a sci-fi interview, and a history written down in the vernacular from an oral narrative. This may look awfully farfetched in theory, but in fact this diversity succeeds in enhancing the message of the book and the pleasure of reading, rather than getting in the way of them. Better still, you get both happy endings and sad endings in a single book, as well as a message, or rather a question, that reverberates through all of the stories and may haunt you for quite a while after leaving Adam Ewing in Honolulu on the final page. Mandatory reading for all lovers of great literature!n when civilization has collapsed completely, but the saddening cycle of human inhumanity is starting all over again nonetheless. Mitchell's versatility of style and genre is dazzling to say the least. Cloud Atlas encompasses a diary, a correspondence, a kafkaesque farce, a racy thriller, a sci-fi interview, and a history written down in the vernacular from an oral narrative. This may look awfully farfetched in theory, but in fact this diversity succeeds in enhancing the message of the book and the pleasure of reading, rather than getting in the way of them. Better still, you get both happy endings and sad endings in a single book, as well as a message, or rather a question, that reverberates through all of the stories and may haunt you for quite a while after leaving Adam Ewing in Honolulu on the final page. Mandatory reading for all lovers of great literature!
0380789019|4.0|Neverwhere was a book I purchased blind to the storyline or author.  I prefer fantasy reads and have exhausted all authors known to me.  I was not enthusiastic about this title while getting through the beginning of the story.  After reading all of Tad Williams novels, I am a bit sick of tunnels!  (as I'm sure fellow fantasy readers can sympathize)  Although, I cannot fault Gaiman for the tunnels, I still feel that I did not find myself into the storyline.  Despite this, the book was consistently interesting and held my attention well. I want to stress the fact that I was always entertained while reading, but I found myself feeling oddly detached from the story (it had a bit of a juvenile feel at time and the way some parts of the story fell together).  As time went on, this book grew on me.  And by the semi-end I loved it.  It really is a unique story.  For me, not everything fit PERFECTLY, as in Tad Williams epics, but it was almost perfect and that is close enough for me.  This book was a fun read.  I will be reading more Gaiman novels in the near future!

B00004Y6NP|5.0|Now, you may have read reviews that question the greatness of this album. I first remember hearing the Cassette around 1987 (5 years old), when I couldn't help but love the tunes So Far Away, Money for Nothing and Walk of Life. It wasn't for another 5 years that I obtained the original CD release. Even in the little boombox that I had, I loved to listen to those first 3 songs. I'd listen to the rest, but I wasn't much into it. <br /> <br />It wasn't until I built an audio system that I came to appreciate the beauty of the album. I knew it was recorded well, but when played through a good system, it really shined. My current setup is a Pioneer VSX-D412 (Amp), Samsung DVD-HD841 (Player), 2 JBL N28II (Front Channel), 2 JBL N26II (Rear Channel), 1 JBL S-CENTER II (Center Channel) and 1 JBL PB12 (Subwoofer). I play all my Stereo in 2.1 (Front and Sub).  <br /> <br />I can listen to this album repeating and never get bored of it. Not only is the music great, it completely changes when listened through a proper system. You get swallowed by the music. Nothing like turning out the lights, closing my eyes and just listen to the entire album. When this album is over, I feel purged, like a new person almost. <br /> <br />Dire Straits in NOT my favorite band, but this is by far, my favorite album.
